results.title: Born yesterday
results.creator_credit: Hollywood Pictures, Touchwood Pacific Partners, Lester Berman, D Constantine Conte and Luis Mandoki
results.brief_description: A remake of the Judy Holliday film from 1950, this version stars Melanie Griffiths in the title role as the gauche mistress of a shady businessman. Keen to enter politics, but reluctant to ditch his liability, he makes her over with the aid of the tutor Paul Verrall (Don Johnson, in the role originally played by William Holden). Billie gains more than just an education however - she falls in love, starts to value herself and begins to recognise the transgressions of her brutish lover. Based on the play by Garson Kanin.

results.title: Born yesterday
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures, S. Sylvan Simon and George Cukor
results.brief_description: Classic Hollywood comedy starring Judy Holliday and William Holden. Judy’s riotous performance as Billy Dawn, the clever ‘dumb blonde’, won her the 1951 Academy Award. Billy, her shady boyfriend and all his thugs move to a Washington hotel to begin wheeling and dealing in the political scene. To get her out of his way, and make her a little more cultured, and dignified, Billy’s gangster boyfriend (Broderick Crawford) hires Holden to teach her. Hilarious scenes and famous lines dot this film which has remained unforgettably and indelibly in the minds of audiences the world over. Based on the stage play by Garson Kanin.

results.title: Born on the fourth of July
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, A. Kitman Ho and Oliver Stone
results.brief_description: Moving away from the simplified morality and broad sweep of his earlier ‘Platoon’ (1986), Stone’s second film on the Vietnam war, based on the 1976 autobiography of Vietnam veteran Ron Kovac, traces two decades in his life. Beginning when Kovac (Tom Cruise) is a zealous teen who eagerly volunteers for the chance to ‘kill commies’, the narrative focuses on his experiences after he is wounded in Vietnam resulting in paralysis from the waist down. Undergoing a slow painful rehabilitation in an underfunded and unsympathetic veteran’s hospital back in the US, he gradually develops a political consciousness and begins to participate in the anti-war movement. An impassioned, compelling film, which is at times, overbearing and bombastic in its exploration of patriotism. Cast also includes Raymond J. Barry, Caroline Kava, Kyra Sedgwick, Brian Larkin, Willem Dafoe, and Lili Taylor.

results.title: Born Free
results.creator_credit: Sam Jaffe, Paul Radin and James Hill
results.brief_description: Perhaps the best loved of all animal films, “Born Free” is based on the real life adventures of Joy Adamson, her husband, and the lion cub, Elsa. Filmed in spectacular African settings, accompanied by an Oscar winning score, “Born Free” is a movie for the entire family. The film sensitively portrays the painful conflict faced by the Adamsons who find they are no longer able to keep the growing Elsa as a pet. Rather than send her to the zoo, they decide to train her for a return to her natural life. Rated G

results.title: Boogie nights
results.creator_credit: New Line Cinema, Lloyd Levin, John Lyons and Paul Thomas Anderson
results.brief_description: Director Paul Thomas Anderson’s second feature is a sprawling, kinetic tribute to the excesses of the 70’s porn industry.”Boogie Nights” follows the rise and fall of Dirk Diggler (Mark Wahlberg), a porn superstar known for his enormous ‘talent’ and loosely based on real life porn actor John Holmes. The film imagines the porn scene as your average dysfuntional family, headed by patriarch Burt Reynolds, an adult film director with lofty ambitions to make quality entertainment. “Boogie Nights” apparent nostalgia for a long gone era is realised via the death of the 16mm porn film, which was replaced by video, a cheaper, mass produced format that changed the industry forever. All this jammed in between one endless party after another, which comes to a sad, abrupt holt once it reaches the 80’s. The excellent ensemble cast includes Julianne Moore, Heather Graham, Don Cheadle, John C. Reilly, William H. Macy, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Luis Guzman, Burt Reynolds, Mark Wahlberg.

results.title: Boiling point = 3-4x jagutsu
results.creator_credit: Bandai, Shockiku-Fuji, Institute of the Contemporary Arts, Hisao Nabeshima, Takio Yoshida, Masayuki Mori and Takeshi Kitano
results.brief_description: Masahiko (Masahiko Ono) is a young gas station attendant whose life revolves around work and baseball. Though usually lazy and inert, Masahiko creates havoc when he punches a rude customer who turns out to be a highly violent gangster. With the gangsters seeking revenge, Masahiko sets out with his best friend to buy a gun in Okinawa. There they meet up with a violent thug (Takeshi Kitano) who takes them on an increasingly absurd road trip in which moral, sexual and criminal codes all become increasingly mixed up. “Beat” Takeshi’s second feature continues his highly idiosyncratic exploration of the gangster film in which operatic moments of violence are contrasted by elegant and largely wordless scenes of contemplation and respite. Kitano’s movies are uniquely personal examinations of masculinity. His own performance in “Boiling Point” as the bisexual misogynist gangster is by turns highly comical and highly confronting. In this ambivalent movie the rituals and cliches of the gangster and yakuza film are both celebrated and the rigorously undermined. The aimless young characters who come into contact with the underworld of crime soon realise that beneath the posturing and display of excess and wealth, there is finally only the shattering certainty of death. It is sometimes said that film noir owes a great debt to existentialism: it may be that Kitano is one of its greatest philosophers.

results.title: Body of evidence
results.creator_credit: De Laurentiis Entertainment Group, Dino De Laurentiis and Uli Edel
results.brief_description: An erotic thriller and murder mystery, “Body of evidence” is probably best remembered for the brouhaha surrounding the sado-masochistic sex games played out before the camera by actors Madonna and Willem Dafoe. Madonna plays a beautiful, sexually aggressive seductress named Rebecca who has a penchant for perilous peccadillos preferably conducted with wealthy men of poor heart condition. When one partner dies in the throes of passion, leaving Rebecca eight million dollars, she is charged with murder. Dafoe plays Frank Dulaney, an ambitious attorney who takes on the case, and despite being uncertain of Rebecca’s innocence, is soon drawn into an amorous relationship that belies his history as a loyal family man. A courtroom drama, not entirely dissimilar in structure to “Witness for the prosecution” (Hitchcock, 1957), this film was released in the wake of the hit “Basic instinct”, but despite matching its salaciousness (and silliness), failed to replicate its success at the box-office. Contains explicit sex scenes and situations but has quite predictably, a morally conservative outcome.

results.title: Body melt
results.creator_credit: 1 for Dumb Films, Australian Film Commission, Film Victoria, Rod Bishop, Daniel Scharf and Philip Brophy
results.brief_description: Something weird is happening in suburban Pebbles Court, Homesville. The residents are unknowingly part of a diabolical experiment with a radical ‘90’s body drug. Some will survive but most will not! The first phase is hallucinogenic, the second phase is glandular and the third phase is Body Melt! “An inventive and laudably tasteless journey into the surreal” Sight & Sound (UK). “Packs more mucous, phlegm, puke, snot, slime and spit than you ever thought possible” Starburst (UK). If you enjoyed “Salt, saliva, sweat and sperm” in the ‘80’s by the same producers and director, then this is the ‘90’S experience you have been craving! Based on four short stories by Philip Brophy. Starring Gerard Kennedy, Ian Smith, Andrew Daddo, Lisa McCune, Brett Climo, Vince Gil and William McInnes.

results.title: Body double [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures and Brian De Palma
results.brief_description: Brian De Palma’s “Body double” - like most of his body of work - are genre exercises which borrow and pay homage to the films of Alfred Hitchcock. The Hitchcock template for this film is “Rear window” and “Vertigo”, perversely reworked into a lurid, violent thriller which proudly wears all it’s sleazy excesses on its sleeve. Craig Wassen plays Jake, a down on his luck actor who has just been fired from a shlock Z-grade vampire film due to his claustrophobia, a problem considering he spends several scenes inside a coffin. Dumped by his girlfriend and evicted from his flat, Jake finds himself homeless until a fellow actor (Gregg Henry) suggests he temporarily house-sit a rich record producer’s house. One of the perks of house-sitting he soon discovers is the sexy neighbour (Deborah Shelton) across the road who loves to undress in front of her window. Soon Jake finds himself obsessively spying on his mysterious neighbour as he inadvertently becomes embroiled in a nasty murder plot. Cast includes Melanie Griffith, Guy Boyd, Dennis Franz.

results.title: Bob Dylan: Don't Look Back
results.creator_credit: Pennebaker Associates, Ashes and Sand, Albert Grossman and D.A. Pennebaker
results.brief_description: An intriguing film biography which captures Dylan during his 1965 English tour. It includes many private moments as well as the public performances. The cast features Joan Baez and Donovan, and tracks include, “Subterranean Homesick Blues”, “The Times They Are A’ Changin’”, and “It’s Alright Ma”.
